altq.php

00001 <table class="manual" id="basic">
00002   <caption>queueing</caption>
00003   <tr>
00004     <th>Statement</th>
00005     <th>Description</th>
00006   </tr>
00007   <tr>
00008     <td colspan="2">
00009       Packets can be assigned to queues for the purpose of bandwidth control.
00010       At least two declarations are required to configure queues, and later any
00011       packet filtering rule can reference the defined queues by name.  During
00012       the filtering component of pf.conf, the last referenced queue name is
00013       where any packets from pass rules will be queued, while for block rules
00014       it specifies where any resulting ICMP or TCP RST packets should be
00015       queued.  The scheduler defines the algorithm used to decide which packets
00016       get delayed, dropped, or sent out immediately.  There are three
00017       schedulers currently supported.
00018     </td>
00019   </tr>
00020   <tr>
00021     <td nowrap="nowrap">cbq</td>
00022     <td>Class Based Queueing.  Queues attached to an interface build a
00023         tree, thus each queue can have further child queues.  Each queue
00024         can have a priority and a bandwidth assigned.  Priority mainly controls 
00025         the time packets take to get sent out, while bandwidth has
00026         primarily effects on throughput.  cbq achieves both partitioning
00027         and sharing of link bandwidth by hierarchically structured classes.
00028         Each class has its own queue and is assigned its share of
00029         bandwidth.  A child class can borrow bandwidth from its parent
00030         class as long as excess bandwidth is available (see the option
00031         borrow, below).
00032     </td>
00033   </tr>
00034   <tr>
00035     <td class="nowrap">priq</td>
00036     <td>Priority Queueing.  Queues are flat attached to the interface,
00037         thus, queues cannot have further child queues.  Each queue has a
00038         unique priority assigned, ranging from 0 to 15.  Packets in the
00039         queue with the highest priority are processed first.
00040     </td>
00041   </tr>
00042   <tr>
00043     <td class="nowrap">hfsc</td>
00044     <td>Hierarchical Fair Service Curve.  Queues attached to an interface
00045         build a tree, thus each queue can have further child queues.  Each
00046         queue can have a priority and a bandwidth assigned.  Priority mainly 
00047         controls the time packets take to get sent out, while bandwidth
00048         has primarily effects on throughput.  hfsc supports both link-sharing 
00049         and guaranteed real-time services.  It employs a service curve
00050         based QoS model, and its unique feature is an ability to decouple
00051         delay and bandwidth allocation.
00052     </td>
00053   </tr>
00054   <tr>
00055     <td colspan="2">
00056       The interfaces on which queueing should be activated are declared using
00057       the altq on declaration. altq on has the following keywords:
00058     </td>
00059   </tr>
00060   <tr>
00061     <td class="nowrap"><strong>interface</strong></td>
00062     <td>Queueing is enabled on the named interface.</td>
00063   </tr>
00064   <tr>
00065     <td class="nowrap"><strong>scheduler</strong></td>
00066     <td>Specifies which queueing scheduler to use. Currently supported
00067         values are cbq for Class Based Queueing, priq for Priority Queueing
00068         and hfsc for the Hierarchical Fair Service Curve scheduler.
00069     </td>
00070   </tr>
00071   <tr>
00072     <td class="nowrap">bandwidth <strong>bw</strong></td>
00073     <td>The maximum bitrate for all queues on an interface may be specified
00074         using the bandwidth keyword. The value can be specified as an ab-
00075         solute value or as a percentage of the interface bandwidth.  When
00076         using an absolute value, the suffixes b, Kb, Mb, and Gb are used to
00077         represent bits, kilobits, megabits, and gigabits per second, respectively.  
00078         The value must not exceed the interface bandwidth. If
00079         bandwidth is not specified, the interface bandwidth is used.
00080     </td>
00081   </tr>
00082   <tr>
00083     <td nowrap="nowrap">qlimit <strong>limit</strong></td>
00084     <td>The maximum number of packets held in the queue. The default is  50.</td>
00085   </tr>
00086   <tr>
00087     <td nowrap="nowrap">tbrsize <strong>size</strong></td>
00088     <td>Adjusts the size, in bytes, of the token bucket regulator. If not
00089         specified, heuristics based on the interface bandwidth are used to
00090         determine the size.
00091     </td>
00092   </tr>
00093   <tr>
00094     <td nowrap="nowrap">queue <strong>list</strong></td>
00095     <td>Defines a list of subqueues to create on an interface.</td>
00096   </tr>
00097   <tr>
00098     <td colspan="2">
00099       <p>In the following example, the interface dc0 should queue up to 5 Mbit/s
00100          in four second-level queues using Class Based Queueing. Those four
00101          queues will be shown in a later example.</p>
00102 
00103         <code>altq on dc0 cbq bandwidth 5Mb queue { std, http, mail, ssh }</code>
00104     </td>
00105   </tr>
00106 </table>
